text:
We’ve had 8 million people join
the Olio community.
The environmental impact

is equivalent to taking over 750 million
car miles off the road.

We've flown over, more than 500
minefields in Ukraine so far.

We're pioneering the use of machine
learning with AWS

to automatically find the mines
in the imagery.
I grew up in a farm in North Yorkshire.
And there, food waste wasn't just a no no.
It was a flat out crime.

And so when I was moving house
a few years ago

and the removal men told me
I had to throw away

all of our uneaten food,
I was not prepared to do that.

And that was the moment when I thought,
this is ridiculous.
Why isn't there an app for this?

We then ran some market research,
and we found that 1 in 3

people said that they were
physically pained throwing away good food.
And so that really galvanised Sasha,
my co-founder, and myself to found Olio.

What was the inspiration
or the rationale behind the HALO trust?
So the HALO trust exists
to clear landmines, all around the world.
We're the world's largest
humanitarian landmine clearance organisation.

We really exist to protect the lives
and restore livelihoods of people

that have been affected by conflict,
because it's not just kind of the danger

of stepping on a landmine
and being injured or killed.

Landmines also stop people
from farming their land, stop children

from going to school, and stop communities
from recovering after a conflict.

And so how many acres of land
have you cleared so far,
and what are your goals and ambitions?

HALO has been around since 1988,
and in that time, we've cleared over

750km² of minefields
as well as a huge amount of other

explosive ordnance
like rockets and cluster munitions.
How long has Olio been in operation?

So next year
we will have been going for ten years.
And we've reached some major milestones.

We've had 8 million people
join the Olio community.

Collectively, they have rescued over
200 million portions of food.

And we've also saved over
13 million household items.

But what we're incredibly proud of is the
environmental and social impact of that.
So the environmental impact

is equivalent to taking over 750 million
car miles off the road.

And we've also saved
30 billion litres of water.
So Olio is just a fantastic example

of how we can harness
the power technology and community

to have a real win win for everybody,
for people, and for the planet.

I heard the story of a farmer named Mikhail
who has a smallholding

which is next door to one of Ukraine's
largest pig farms.

After the full scale invasion started in 2022,
the majority of the pigs
actually starved to death.

And then the ones that didn't were later
killed by stepping on landmines.
The family actually run out of food

in three months after the 
invasion started.

HALO is currently clearing Mikhail’s land
so that he can return to farming.

Some farmers in his position
decide that they can't afford to wait

and decide to farm their land
anyway, with often tragic consequences.

We have countless stories
that really reinforce for us
the power of what we're doing.
we hear on a daily basis from parents

in particular, who are incredibly grateful
for the fact that they can use Olio

to access food for their children
when they're having a really tough time.

It was immediately obvious to us
we had massive ambitions.

We needed to have a service solution
that would scale with us.

And so AWS was the obvious choice,
and AWS has been with us at every point

on our journey, and it's really felt like
we've had a toolbox beside us.
And at any point in time,

we can take out whichever tool
that we want to solve that problem.

In a really efficient,
resourceful, cost effective way.

One of the technologies we’ve been trialing
in the last two years is the use of drones

to fly over suspected areas of minefields
and take images of the minefields.

We've flown over, more than 500
minefields in Ukraine so far.

We've produced over 11TB of data
so far too much for any one person

to search through manually,
which is where the AI comes into it.
So we're pioneering the use of machine

learning with AWS to automatically
find the mines in the imagery.
So 11TB of data, that is a huge amount,
it's a lot to deal with.

And that's something that we have
as a bit of a challenge as well.

So we have millions of items that are
being shared via the app each month.

And what we like to do is provide people
with their impact data,

and we need to calculate that impact
for them

real time as all the sharing activity’s
taking place.

And so we use the AWS caching service
so we don't slow down
the main experience of the app.
We can use the cache data

to make our calculations
and then give that back to our community.
We've also really leant into AI

as well, so we've developed
this tool called AI-ify.

And when you're adding a listing
to the app, you can just tap that button

and it will automatically complete
the title and the description.

So it makes the process of adding listings
to the app much faster.
The same for us really

AI is just speeding up what we can do
and allowing us
to return land to safe use more quickly.

Our eyes have really been opened
by the ability of technology

to accelerate what we're doing,
and not just the small data

processing parts of the pipeline,
but the overall process has sped up.
